subject: Philosophy
title: Bayesian Reasoning
description: A micro-lesson that makes Bayesian Reasoning usable.

hook.text: A medical test is 99% accurate. You test positive. What's the chance you're actually sick? Much less than 99%.

buildup.text: Bayes' theorem shows how to update beliefs based on new evidence â€” combining prior knowledge with fresh data.

discovery.text: If a disease is rare, even an accurate test will produce many false positives. Prior probability matters.

twist.text: Humans are terrible at Bayesian reasoning. We overreact to dramatic evidence and ignore base rates.

climax.text: Bayesian thinking is now used in medicine, AI, and law. It's the closest thing to a rational belief system.

punchline.text: New evidence changes the odds. It doesn't replace them.

quiz.question: What does Bayes' theorem help you do?
options: Update beliefs rationally based on new evidence
